ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Subject matter is crucial, a lot of interest from students, but the organization was a little rocky.
The readings were often long and not needed to understand the course content. I would prefer the lectures to be more academically rigorous and based on the readings.
Fascinating course! The multiple instructor model was a bit chaotic at times and would feel more cohesive with fewer instructors in charge.

I greatly enjoyed this course and found the combination of student-led discussions and professor-led lectures to be very useful. However, I believe it would be helpful to have more continuous assignments for the class. Additionally, it would be helpful to receive feedback about individual performance earlier in the semester.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Broad survey to very interesting material which is difficult to access otherwise. Marian and Reid have incredible experience and knowledge.
Wonderful introduction to a field I've been curious about but had no background with.
the lectures
The content
The student presentations offered the most interesting aspects of waste management.
The lectures were very interesting and the class was fun overall.

The lectures and discussion, the material covered was illuminating and expanded my perspective on the issues of waste management. For me, it was like getting a broad overview of the big pictures of a subject area within which I study tiny details. Sort of putting the earth in the context of the solar system. I've wanted that perspective for a long time and I'm glad to have it. The lectures and discussion were almost always informative, approachable and built towards that understanding.
The best part was being able to discuss waste in an academic context with others interested in the topic.
This is the only course on campus that will give you any exposure to waste, so if you think you might be interested or may need that exposure, you should take it.
The depth of expertise in the professor's experience and knowledge base.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Need to figure out how to maximize the ability of Marian and Reid to teach the students. The distribution of teaching, across faculty, TAs, and students was not helpful, rushed the classroom experience, resulted in inefficient allocation of teaching time based off level of experience.

Structure of the class felt unbalanced. Every week was a sprint to finish the first lecture, then followed by a student presentation that felt drawn out and sometimes boring or unprepared. Maybe more like 80 minutes of professor lecture, followed by something a little shorter and more to the point by the students? Also, I think we definitely should have visited a landfill or MRF. Seems like it would have augmented learning, and why not?
the student led discussions
I prefer lectures than student led discussions

The teaching team was quite large and not always on the same page when it came to direction. It was hard to prepare for student presentations because it felt as though Reid had very different ideas of what was expected than Marian. The class was also very quantitative and lacked real life applicability for waste managers. It would have been more helpful to draw in case studies and real world examples to help drive points home. The readings were often very technical and difficult to comprehend or synthesize.

The student led portions of the lecture were often not useful for learning more about waste. The grading rubrics were very vague, while at the same time the grading was harsh. Tough grading is fine but not when it is combined with unclear expectations.

The instructors of this course need to be more organized in their expectations and get on the same page a lot of the time. I and my fellow students frequently felt like we were getting different feed back or instruction on the submitted work from different instructors. Or perhaps were told by one instructor that content was appropriate and then lost points on their grade for using said content. Also, students need to be given feed back sooner. I have never taken course at yale or otherwise where I was given no feedback at all on my standing in the course until five days before the final assignment for the course was due. The faculty were extremely kind an understanding in letting me have more time to work on my final material to address the grade issue, however, I would have been able to get a lot more out of that process if I hadn't been doing it during finals week. About 25 hours of work was added to my finals week in this process and though it was a worth while endeavor, it would have been so much more appropriate and fruitful during the semester. I requested feed back a month before I was given any and this process could easily have happened during that month if i had known the severity of the situation. that be being said, I was very happy with the progress I made in my writing, the improvement in my paper and the extension which was given so I was able to address the grade issue at all.
Allow more time in class for group discussions on readings and themes presented in the lecture.

The teaching team is quite arrogant and unresponsive to student needs. Often they would act like students were asking stupid questions or missing some important concept, without explaining what that might is. The condescending attitudes and "devil's advocate" approach of some of the team was not conducive to learning, especially for those new to the content. The course content is also very weak- it is too technical and obscure for what students need to learn. Most of it is a presentation of data, rather than any kind of synthesis or analysis. We need to understand trends and themes, not minutiae!
I didn't like that half of every class was spent on student presentations. It made everything feel really rushed
This course was profoundly disorganized and frustrating. It may improve with time but I would advise against taking it for the next few years until they figure out what they want it to be.
Need more practical topics and examples

1) structure: it felt a little loosey goosey in the second half with various student presentations. 2) design: a lot of breadth is covered in this class, which made it feel rather "college seminar" like. If that was the goal, then okay, its design was congruent with the execution. But if this was to make appreciable gains in certain substantive areas of wast emanagement, I'd cut down on the number of topics and immerse a little bit greater. 3) assigning readings and not lecturing on them or about them is kind of a waste of time. the readings sometimes felt complimentary and ancillary to what's being taught in the class.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: The CIE has a lot of money, and knowing about these themes means I can apply for scholarships and funding. This may sound crass but it's been a huge boon for me.
its an elective for my track
I think it was difficult to understand some of the terminology and processes described in this course without a background in waste and/ or industrial ecology.
I was very interested in waste when entering the Industrial Ecology program, so this course tied together some of the gaps in my knowledge that will apply to other courses.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: interest in the subject

I wanted to learn how waste is managed and what sustainable waste management might look like in the future, particularly as urban populations continue to grow and the world becomes more developed and affluent.
I wanted to solidify my understanding of waste from an academic context.
This was the only course on waste that could align with general interests in product stewardship/corporate sustainability.
I am passionate about sanitation equity and thought this course would accent my previous training while exposing me to emerging aspects of waste and materials management.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Underwhelming.
I learned more than I thought possible about landfills, and yet I now know that that's only scratching the surface.
yes

Not really- while I learned some from this class it won't be as helpful as I hoped in my career. It seemed like an appropriate class for people who want to do waste research in the future, which I would say is probably a minority group of FES students.
Yes.
Yes, I learned more material in this class that I will use on a regular basis, in life, and in formulating research, than in almost any other class at yale.
Yes, I have a better understanding for the different types of waste management, as well as potential frontiers and challenges facing the industry.
Not really. I didn't learn big themes regarding current waste issues, or any kind of big picture trends about frontiers. Most of the information that was new to me was very piecemeal and disjointed.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Little direction and instruction from course faculty. Vision for student presentations was incomplete.

It was helpful to discuss the project with other students who brought in their own background work and expertise. However, as students, we had a different idea on how our presentation should go than the direction given form the teaching team. The group wok work was presented as an opportunity for students to seek out the aspects of waste that interested them most, but in the end, it seemed as though we were limited to what the teaching team liked/ believed in/ agreed upon.

I do not think it is appropriate that grades were assigned the same to each student in the team. For example, some students were clearly not prepared for their lecture, while other students worked with professors to develop appropriate content.

This was probably the worst part. Both of us struggled hard to be able to find content that would satisfy expectations. We both felt woefully underprepared to be giving a lecture on something we knew nothing about and struggled to find evidence of. Also, in my opinion, my partner wildly misrepresented the content and quality of what she was going to present. She did not follow the schedule we had in mind and thus our discussion session went completely differently than we had agreed to and much of the work i put into that part of the presentation when entirely to waste. I know that learning to work with others is important but its frustrating to be graded with another adult who you trust to act one way and then does something completely unexpected.
The group presentations were sometimes a bit scattered but overall added good variety to the course.
It was too short of a time frame to really create something meaningful and important
My team mate was not cooperative in the presentation time

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Do it. FES needs more classes about the down and dirty parts of the world. This class feels like a spiritual successor to some of the old classic forestry classes.
participate as much as possible

I would say students should consider what they hope to learn and what they plan to do with that knowledge. If you are looking for more practical understanding and application of waste management, this probably isn't the class for you. Then again, there are very few waste classes at FES, so this might be the only option for students right now.

The class is great, you will have fun and learn a ton. Worry about your grades and communicate with the faculty about your intentions and their response to your work early and often. More so than you might think necessary.
Be prepared to spend a lot of time reading and thinking about waste!

Keep your expectations for this class low, especially if you are somewhat familiar with waste issues. Also, don't expect this to be tailored to private sector issues- most of the content and readings are at the macroeconomic, societal level. The teaching team is quite haughty and may make you feel stupid. That's just their style/personalities, don't let it stop you from voicing your opinion or asking questions when you don't understand. Be prepared to put in quite a bit of work for the in-class group presentation, as well as the paper at the end. They make both assignments more complex than they need to be.
Your time would be better spent with another course - you won't cover much in this course that you couldn't learn on your own time.
